Watching John Cassavetes film, Opening Night, I was reminded of something that Quentin Tarantino said once in an interview about personal experience in being a creator. He said:
“I don’t think there’s any kind of fear of what we bring. You get to know the person early on. It’s about what you bring to the project. Tune into what is accessible and honest and significant in your life. Learn when to play to your strengths, and when not to.”

So should I like this? Yes it was a great film,

I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it. "Les Valseuses" was remade as "Hard and Aft" by Blake Edwards. The film is about a couple of juvenile delinquent pals played by Patrick O’Neal and Danny Vadivelu looking for a quick buck. A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat-loving witch (Deborah Harrell), a revenge-seeking neighbor (Ken Hicks) and an accidental murder. Well, it is an adaptation of and homage to "Hate" and other horror films of the '70's/80's, a time when I was just old enough to love horror films of all kind
